thread.title: Japan stocks rise, but other Asia stocks struggle after weak U.S. lead - MarketWatch
thread.title_full: Japan stocks rise, but other Asia stocks struggle after weak U.S. lead - MarketWatch

author: Jake Maxwell Watts
title: Japan stocks rise, but other Asia stocks struggle after weak U.S. lead - MarketWatch
text:
Asian stocks began mixed Wednesday on weak lead from the U.S., with much of the focus on the start of earnings season after a tough quarter for many companies.
Japan’s Nikkei Stock Average NIK, +1.86% was 1.8% higher at 18,535.95 during the morning session. Australia’s S&P/ASX 200 XJO, +0.31% was up 0.3% and New Zealand’s benchmark index edged 0.2% higher. China’s Shanghai Composite SHCOMP, +0.39% rose 0.3%. Markets in Hong Kong are closed for a holiday.
Overnight , U.S. markets offered little in the way of a clear lead for Asia.
“A sluggish U.S. session following equally weak European trade points toward a tepid start to Asian equity markets,” said IG Markets strategist Bernard Aw.
Both the Dow Jones Industrial Average DJIA, -0.08% and the S&P 500 SPX, -0.14% fell 0.1%, dragged lower by IBM’s IBM, -5.75% tumble to a five-year low after the company reported weaker-than-expected results.
Fortescue Metals Group FMG, +6.17% is among the strongest stocks in Australia, rising 3.8% in early trade to its highest level in four months on heavy volume. BHP Billiton BHP, -0.82% BHP, +1.50% BLT, -0.27% was 0.4% higher after it said Wednesday it would scale back investment plans for its petroleum division. Among Japanese shares, Pioneer 6773, +7.28% and Sony SNE, -0.73% 6758, +4.56% are among the strongest performers, up 7.3% and 3.4%, respectively.
In Singapore, Wilmar International F34, -0.63% was down as much as 1.3% at 3.13 Singapore dollars (US$2.25) a share, after Archer Daniels Midland ADM, -0.59% increased its stake in the Asian agricultural business.
Wilmar shares rose 8.9% in the previous trading session before the firm said ADM had bought 22% of shares traded Tuesday.
The city-state’s benchmark stock index was 0.6% higher in the first hour after the open.
In foreign-exchange markets, the Japanese yen USDJPY, +0.11% was slightly weaker at ¥119.95 against the U.S. dollar, indicating a muted reaction to weaker-than-expected Japanese trade data.
Japan said early Wednesday that September exports grew 0.6% from a year earlier , undershooting the 3.4% forecast by economists. Imports slumped 11.1%.
At Tuesday’s close in Asia, the U.S. dollar bought ¥119.64.
Malaysia’s ringgit slid 0.5% against the U.S. dollar and Korea’s won strengthened 0.1%.
In the absence of major economic data, the main short-term focus for many traders is how companies have fared during the turbulent third quarter. Some of the region’s largest firms are scheduled to report results in the coming days.
Stocks and currency markets have gyrated over the past three months on concerns about a slowdown in China and its impact on global growth. Data issued this week showed the world’s second-largest economy grew 6.9% in the third quarter, but many economists are skeptical of that figure.
“The flow of U.S. earnings reports will continue to exert a significant influence on trading sentiment today” in Asia, said Singapore’s United Overseas Bank in a note. It added that Japan’s weak export data could “further tilt market expectation” for the Bank of Japan to take further easing steps at its policy meeting next week.
Crude oil prices fell slightly after rebounding Tuesday. Brent crude was 0.4% lower at US$48.50 a barrel.
Write to Jake Maxwell Watts at jake.watts@wsj.com
